name: Kepler-111
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-111 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-111 is a star with 1.2739999999999998 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.16 times its radius. It is located 2184.98 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-111 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-111 b

Kepler-111 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.34 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-111.

The mass of Kepler-111 b is 2.89 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-111 b is 1.58 that of Earth. At 2.89 Earth masses, Kepler-111 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-111 c

Kepler-111 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.76 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 224.78 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-111.

The mass of Kepler-111 c is 113.44 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-111 c is 7.3 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, Kepler-111 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-111, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
